channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Editor Whose Ouster Stirred Protests Is Slashed
item.description: The slashing of the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper comes just a month after he was dismissed from a job in which he oversaw reporting that was critical of the mainland Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A police officer standing by the car of Kevin Lau, the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper who was stabbed Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Steel Mill Closes, Guangzhou Loses a Piece of Its History
item.description: The Guangzhou Steel factory, formerly a small, semi-independent city of its own, with 6,000 workers, has largely fallen silent.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Staircases rusting away at what remains of the Guangzhou Steel mill, ordered shut down in 2010.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Beijing, Complaints About Smog Grow Louder and Retaliation Grows Swifter
item.description: Anger is rising over the government’s inability to protect the nation from pollution that has made places like the capital “unsuitable for human habitation,” as a prominent think tank stated this month in a study that was swiftly censored.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Visitors are silhouetted against thick smog at Jingshan Park near the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Swiss Turn Inward, by a Thin Margin
item.description: Voters in Switzerland have chosen to put a stop to mass immigration. The result sent shock waves across Europe.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Car Bomb Kills 14, Raising Day’s Toll to 26
item.description: A parked car bomb blew up by a crowded Baghdad market on Tuesday night, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Police Error Frees Bombing Suspect
item.description: A man accused of killing four British soldiers in a bombing in London in 1982 will not face trial because he was mistakenly told that he was not wanted by the police.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: New Coalition Takes On India’s Two Biggest Parties
item.description: The alliance of smaller parties comes at a time when opinion polls show regional parties could be key to forming a government if no party wins a majority in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Sharad Yadav, leader of the Janata Dal (United) party, arriving for a meeting of Left and regional parties in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: New Twist Emerges in ’86 Murder of Swedish Premier
item.description: A Swedish newspaper published new information linking a former military officer, with connections to South Africa, to the murder of Olof Palme, Sweden’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Lawyers for American Couple Seek Inquiry in Qatar
item.description: Matthew and Grace Huang face a verdict soon in the death of their adopted daughter, but they have questioned the results of her autopsy.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Russian Opposition Leaders Get Jail Terms
item.description: The activist Aleksei A. Navalny was among those sentenced for resisting arrest.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Hired to Fight Pirates, but Doomed by Boredom
item.description: Mystery surrounds the deaths of two former members of the Navy SEALs, working as ship guards, who were found inside the cabin of the Maersk Alabama, made famous by a 2009 hijacking.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH IAN URBINA and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: The Maersk Alabama in 2009, the year pirates hijacked it in an episode that inspired the movie “Captain Phillips.” Two guards were recently found dead in a cabin onboard the container vessel.

item.title: El Chapo’s Arrest Unlikely to Break Mexican Cartel
item.description: Many officials say the Sinaloa cartel has transcended its leader, Joaquín (El Chapo) Guzmán Loera, learning better than its competitors how to produce and move drugs, establish new markets and outsource business.
item.dc:creator: By GINGER THOMPSON and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera on Saturday. His arrest is a challenge for his cartel, but many experts say it is not necessarily devastating.

item.title: Crude Weapons Help Fuel Unrest in Bastion of Venezuelan Opposition
item.description: Protesters are using a variety of homemade weapons against troops, including miniature firebombs and Miguelitos, which are made from hoses festooned with nails.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in San Cristóbal, Venezuela, funneled gasoline to make Molotov cocktails. Demonstrators have built barriers on nearly every block, gridlocking the city.

item.title: An Unfinished Ukraine Palace and a Fugitive Leader’s Folly
item.description: Workers hired to build a retreat for Viktor F. Yanukovych have walked off the job, since he will never be able to pay them after his ouster as Ukraine’s president.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Work on a retreat for Viktor F. Yanukovych stopped after his ouster as Ukraine’s president.

item.title: Editorial: North Korea’s Atrocities
item.description: A United Nations report has produced the most authoritative indictment yet of crimes against humanity unparalleled in the contemporary world.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Tentatively, European Union Weighs Its Options on Support for a New Ukraine
item.description: The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said at a news conference that Europe would offer “support, not interference,” and urged Ukrainians to maintain good ties with Russia.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Catherine Ashton, left, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, met in Kiev on Tuesday with Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister who was freed from prison.

item.title: Infighting Poses Hurdle to Formation of New Coalition in Ukraine
item.description: Formation of an interim government was delayed until at least Thursday as regional and ideological rifts divide the nation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Kiev's Independence Square on Tuesday mourned those killed in recent demonstrations.

item.title: Memo From Istanbul: Turks Are Glued to a Sensational Drama, This One Political
item.description: Although the Turkish period drama “The Magnificent Century” has become an obsession in the country, the show gripping many Turks is their nation’s own political crisis.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who spoke to lawmakers on Tuesday, faces the greatest challenge to his power in years.

item.title: The Lede: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Tweets at the President
item.description: Henrique Capriles, the country’s most prominent opposition leader, opted not to meet with President Nicolás Maduro, saying Mr. Maduro’s invitation had been intended only to create a photo opportunity.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: Reversing Course, Japan Makes Push to Restart Dormant Nuclear Plants
item.description: The government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe reversed course on a promise made by a previous government to phase out the country’s atomic power plants.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Trust Eroded, Obama Looks Beyond Karzai
item.description: President Obama is apparently resigned to dealing with the next Afghan president on troop withdrawals and training, since President Hamid Karzai has refused to sign a long-term security agreement.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: American soldiers on Tuesday near Kandahar, Afghanistan, after meeting with officials at an Afghan National Police outpost.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: With Syria, Diplomacy Needs Force
item.description: Assad won’t negotiate a cease-fire without military pressure.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL IGNATIEFF

item.title: The Lede: Ukrainian Journalists Launch YanukovychLeaks
item.description: Hundreds of documents found at the abandoned presidential retreat outside Kiev since Ukraine’s leader fled the capital have been posted on a new site, YanukovychLeaks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Lede: Day After Uganda’s Antigay Law Is Signed, a Tabloid Publishes Names
item.description: Fears of a violence were heightened by the publication and photographs of names of gay and lesbian Ugandans, with some people recalling David Kato’s death in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: The Lede: Navalny Is Convicted of Resisting Arrest at Moscow Protest, Despite Video Evidence
item.description: Three Russian dissidents arrested during protests in Moscow argued that images posted on social networks undermined police claims that they had resisted arrest or waved banners.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
